newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African court denies Moslem activists bail.
newsitem.headline: S.African court denies Moslem activists bail.

text.p: South African prosecutors on Wednesday refused bail to 24 Moslem militants arrested after an anti-drug rally turned violent and demonstraters attacked a police station where their supporters had been detained.
Western Cape Attorney General Frank Khan said he had instructed his staff to oppose bail for the members of the People Against Gangsterism and Drugs (Pagad), a predominantly Moslem movement.
Some 100 supporters gathered outside the Bellville magistrates' court on Wednesday, where police wearing bullet-proof vests had thrown up a cordon and blocked the suburb's main street.
"Their case will be postponed to Friday and all the accused will remain in custody," he told Reuters, adding they would submit further information to him before the next hearing.

A senior prosecutor said Pagad leaders Aslam Toefy and Abdul-Salaam Ebrahim were ordered to surrender to police by Thursday afternoon or face arrest for their role in arranging Monday's anti-drugs protest.
Monday's clashes began when about 200 Pagad supporters refused to disperse after an unauthorised demonstration outside Cape Town's international airport.
Thirteen people were arrested at the airport and several others were injured by stones, rubber bullets and police dogs.

Five policemen were seriously wounded later on Monday when Pagad supporters, many of them masked with Palestinian-style scarves, attacked the suburban Bellville police station where the suspects were held.
Khan said he met Pagad lawyers on Wednesday but was not convinced to support bail for the 24 people facing charges ranging from attempted murder to joining an illegal gathering.
Police on Tuesday suspended talks with Pagad, saying the movement had become "just another gang."
"Pagad is now firmly a part of the crime problem and not the solution in the Western Cape," said acting national police commissioner Zolisa Lavisa.
Pagad sprang to prominence in August when supporters publicly shot and burned to death a known drug baron in Cape Town.
The organisation calls for tougher police action against gangsters and drug lords and rejects any legal action against its own members until the gang problem is resolved.
